Discrete-Time LTI Systems: The Convolution Sum

The Representation of Discrete-Time Signals in Terms of Impulses

This corresponds to the representation of an arbitrary sequence as a linear combination of shifted unit impulses $\delta[n-k]$, where the weights in this linear combination are $x[k]$.

Convolution-Sum Representation of Discrete-Time LTI Systems

Consider the response of a linear system to an arbitrary input $x[n]$. We can represent the input as a linear combination of shifted unit impulses. Let $h_k[n]$ denote the response of the linear system to the shifted unit impulse $\delta[n-k]$. Then, from the superposition property for a linear system, the response $y[n]$ of the linear system to the input $x[n]$ is simply the weighted linear combination of these basic responses. That is, with the input $x[n]$ to a linear system expressed in the form of $x[n]=\sum\limits_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty}x[k]\delta[n-k]$, the output $y[n]$ can be expressed as

Thus, if we know the response of a linear system to the set of shifted unit impulses, we can construct the response to an arbitrary input.
In general, the responses $h_k[n]$ need not be related to each other for different values of k. However, if the linear system is also time invariant, then these responses to time-shifted unit impulses are all time-shifted versions of each other. Specifically, since $\delta[n-k]$ is a time-shifted version of $\delta[n]$, the response $h_k[n]$ is a time-shifted version of $h_0[n]$; i.e.,

For notational convenience, we will drop the subscript on $h_0[n]$ and define the unit impulse (sample) response

That is, $h[n]$ is the output of the LTI system when $\delta[n]$ is the input. Then for an LTI system,

This result is referred to as the convolution sum or superposition sum, and the operation on the right-hand side is known as the convolution of the sequences $x[n]$ and $h[n]$. We will represent the operation of convolution symbolically as

An LTI system is completely characterized by its response to a single signal, namely, its response to the unit impulse.

The Representation of Continuous-Time Signals in Terms of Impulses

As in discrete time, we refer to this as the sifting property of the continuous-time impulse.

Convolution Integral Representation of Continuous-Time LTI Systems

This represents the general form of the response of a linear system in continuous time. If, in addition to being linear, the system is also time invariant, then $h_ au(t) = h_0(t- au)$; i.e., the response of an LTI system to the unit impulse $\delta(t- au)$, which is shifted by $ au$ seconds from the origin, is a similarly shifted version of the response to the unit impulse function $\delta(t)$. Again, for notational convenience, we will drop the subscript and define the unit impulse response $h(t)$ as

This referred to as the convolution integral or the superposition integral, is the continuous-time counterpart of the convolution sum and corresponds to the representation of a continuous-time LTI system in terms of its response to a unit impulse. Causality for LTI Systems

The output of a causal system depends only on the present and past values of the input to the system.
Specifically, in order for a discrete-time LTI system to be causal, $y[n]$ must not depend on $x[k]$ for $k>n$.This then requires that the impulse response of a causal discrete-time LTI system satisfy the condition

Causality for a linear system is equivalent to the condition of initial rest; i.e., if the input to a causal system is 0 up to some point in time, then the output must also be 0 up to that time. It is important to emphasize that the equivalence of causality and the condition of initial rest applies only to linear systems.

While causality is a property of systems, it is common terminology to refer to a signal as being causal if it is zero for $n<0$ or $t<0$. Causality of an LTI system is equivalent to its impulse response being a causal signal.

Stability for LTI Systems

The Unit Step Response of an LTI System

There is another signal that is also used quite often in describing the behavior of LTI systems: the unit step response, $s[n]$ or $s(t)$, corresponding to the output when $x[n]=u[n]$ or $x(t)=u(t)$.
From the convolution-sum representation, the step response of a discrete-time LTI system is the convolution of the unit step with the impulse response; that is

And $h[n]$ can be recovered from $s[n]$ using the relation

Similarly, in continuous time, the step response of an LTI system with impulse response $h(t)$ is given by

And the unit impulse response is the first derivative of the unit step response

Causal LTI Systems Described by Differential and Difference Equations

Linear Constant-Coefficient Differential Equations

A general $N$th-order linear constant-coefficient differential equation is given by

The order refers to the highest derivative of the output $y(t)$ appearing in the equation. In the case when $N=0$, the general differential equation reduces to

In this case, $y(t)$ is an explicit function of the input $x(t)$ and its derivatives. For $N\geqslant 1$, the equation specifies the output implicitly in terms of the input. The solution $y(t)$ consists of two parts: a particular solution to the general differential equation plus a solution to the homogeneous differential equation

The solutions to this equation are referred to as the natural responses of the system.
As in the first-order case, the general differential equation does not completely specify the output in terms of the input, and we need to identify auxiliary conditions to determine completely the input-output relationship for the system. Once again, different choices for these auxiliary conditions result in different input-output relationships, but for the most part, in this book we will use the condition of initial rest when dealing with systems described by differential equations. That is, if $x(t)=0$ for $t\leqslant t_{0}$, we assume that $y(t)=0$ for $t\leqslant t_{0}$, and therefore, the response for $t>t_{0}$ can be calculated from the general differential equation with the initial conditions

Under the condition of initial rest, the system described by the general differential equation is causal and LTI.

Linear Constant-Coefficient Difference Equations

The discrete-time counterpart of the differential equation is the $N$th-order linear constant-coefficient difference equation

An equation of this type can be solved in a manner exactly analogous to that for differential equations. Specifically, the solution $y[n]$ can be written as the sum of a particular solution to the general difference equation and a solution to the homogeneous equation

The solutions to this homogeneous equation are often referred to as the natural responsesof the system described by the general difference equation.
As in the continuous-time case, the general difference equation does not completely specify the output in terms of the input. We will focus for the most part on the condition of initial rest, if x$[n]=0$ for $n<n_{0}$, then $y[n]=0$ for $n<n_{0}$ as well. With initial rest, the system described by the general difference equation is LTI and causal.
Although all of these properties can be developed following an approach that directly parallels our discussion for differential equations, the discrete-time case offers an alternative path. This stems from the observation that the general difference equation can be rearranged in the form

This is called a recursive equation since it specifies a recursive procedure for determining the output in terms of the input and previous outputs. In the special case when $N=0$, the recursive equation reduces to

This equation describes an LTI system, and by direct computation, the impulse response of this system is found to be

That is, this equation is nothing more than the convolution sum. Note that the impulse response for it has finite duration; that is, it is nonzero only over a finite time interval. Because of this property, the system specified by this equation is often called a finite impulse response (FIR) system.

Block Diagram Representations of First-Order Systems Described by Differential and Difference Equations

Basic elements for the block diagram representation of the causal system described by a difference equation: (a) an adder; (b) multiplication by a coefficient; (c) a unit delay.

An example, for equation $$ rac{\operatorname{d}y(t)}{\operatorname{d}t}+ay(t)=bx(t)$$
While the figure is a valid representation of the causal system described by the differential equation, it is not the representation that is most frequently used or the representation that leads directly to practical implementations, since differentiators are both difficult to implement and extremely sensitive to errors and noise. An alternative implementation that is much more widely used can be obtained by first rewriting the differential equation as$$ rac{dy(t)}{dt}=bx(t)-ay(t)$$and then integrating from $-\infty$ to $t$. Specifically, if we assume that in the system described by the differential equation the value of $y(-\infty)$ is zero, then the integral of $ rac{dy(t)}{dt}$ from $\infty$ to $t$ is precisely $y(t)$. Periodicity Properties

The oscillation speed of $e^{j\omega_0n}$ increases in $0<\omega_0<\pi$, decreases in $\pi<\omega_0<2\pi$In order for the signal $e^{j\omega_0n}$ to be periodic with period $N>0$,

So the signal $e^{j\omega_0n}$ is periodic if $\frac{\omega_0}{2\pi}$ is a rational number.
If $x[n]$ is periodic with fundamental period $N=m(\frac{2\pi}{\omega_0})$, its fundamental frequency is $\frac{2\pi}{N}=\frac{\omega_0}{m}$.

The Unit Impulse and Unit Step Functions

Discrete-Time

The discrete-time unit impulse (or unit sample):

The discrete-time unit step:

The discrete-time unit impulse is the first difference of the discrete-time step.

The discrete-time step is the running sum of the unit impulse.

The unit impulse sequence can be used to sample the value of a signal at n=0. In particular, $\delta[n]$is nonzero only for n=0,

More generally, consider a unit impulse $\delta[n-n_0]$, then

Continuous-Time

The continuous-time unit step

The continuous-time impulse is the first derivative of the unit step.

The continuous-time step is the running integral of the unit impulse.

The continuous-time impulse has an important sampling property.

Basic System Properties

System with and without memory

A system is said to be memoryless if its output for each value of the independent variable at a given time is dependent on the input at only that same time.
An example of a discrete-time system with memory is an accumulator or summer:

And a second example is a delay:

An example of a continuous-time system with memory is a capacitor, if the input is the current and the output is the voltage:

Invertibility and Inverse Systems

A system is said to be invertible if distinct inputs lead to distinct outputs. If a system is invertible, then an inverse system exists that, when cascaded with the original system, yields an output $w[n]$ equal to the input $x[n]$ to the first system.

Causality

A system is causal if the output at any time depends on values of the input at only the present and past times. Such a system is often referred to as being non-anticipative, as the system output does not anticipate future values of the input. Consequently, if two inputs to a causal system are identical up to some point in time $t_0$ or $n_0$ , the corresponding outputs must also be equal up to this same time.

Stability

The bounded-input bounded-output (BIBO) stability implies that for every bounded input, $u(t):|u(t)|<M_1<\infty$, the output of the system stays bounded, that is, $y(t):|y(t)|<M_2<∞$.

Time Invariance

A system is time invariant if the behavior and characteristics of the system are fixed over time.
Specifically, a system is time invariant if a time shift in the input signal results in an identical time shift in the output signal. That is, if $y[n]$ is the output of a discrete-time, time-invariant system when $x[n]$ is the input,
then $y[n-n_0]$ is the output when $x[n-n_0]$ is applied. In continuous time with $y(t)$ the output corresponding to the input $x(t)$, a time-invariant system will have $y(t-t_0)$ as the
output when $x (t-t_0)$ is the input.

Linearity

Let $y_1(t)$ be the response of a continuoustime system to an input $x_1(t)$, and let $y_2(t)$ be the output corresponding to the input $x_2(t)$.Then the system is linear if:

  1. Additivity or superposition property: The response to $x_1(t)+x_2(t)$ is $y_1(t)+y_2(t)$.
  2. Scaling or homogeneity property: The response to $ax_1(t)$ is $ay_1(t)$, where $a$ is any complex constant.

The two properties defining a linear system can be combined into a single statement:

Here, $a$ and $b$ are any complex constants.

entry.title: 失真效果器的制作
entry.content:
初次尝试

第一次开始尝试自制效果器还是在去年年底，在CSDN上找到了一个博主自制失真效果器的文章：自制电吉他效果器 DIY，便照着文章自己做了一下，电路板焊接还算成功，但是由于本身电路设计就很粗糙，最后测试音色感觉太干，不能拿去实际使用。

电路图绘制

采用Altium Designer软件，按照那位博主的电路图绘制。

PCB板绘制

其中有几个元件在原生库里没有封装，我自己画了封装，当时我还是第一次使用这个软件，过程还是蛮麻烦的。

PCB板打印&元件焊接

打印PCB板的厂家我选的是嘉立创，速度还行而且价格很便宜(甚至五张不超过10*10cm的样板免费)。

由于之前有焊接电路板的经验，焊接过程可以说是轻车熟路，不到两个小时就焊完了并且没出什么差错。

插上电源，接上吉他的时候发现能正常工作，还是蛮开心的。但是音色确实不太行。所以我又萌生了复刻大厂经典效果器的想法。

BOSS SD-1 Overdrive的复刻

BOSS在效果器行业的地位绝对是毋庸置疑的，并且发布于1981年的SD-1 Overdrive一直以来销量都很高，网络上也能找到现成的电路图，所以我选择先复刻这款经典效果器。

电路图绘制

PCB板绘制

之前第一次尝试画PCB板的时候有很多设计得不好的地方，这次我逐一做了改进。

元件分层设计

这次在元件的分布上我采用了双层设计，除发光二极管以外的贴片元件都放在了bottom layer，直插元件都放在了top layer，这样更方便焊接，也能缩小板子的面积，给top overlay层留出更大的空间印图案。

电源、输入输出接口位置调整

上次我画的电源接口的位置属实下饭，离板子边缘还有不小距离，导致没办法设计装壳。于是这次我专门等元件都到货之后再开始画封装和PCB板，量好各个元件的尺寸后将电源、输入输出接口的位置都调整到了板子边缘，方便装壳。

最终效果

PCB板打印&元件焊接

依旧嘉立创(免费打样+包邮，着实令人感动)。

暂停说明

最近这段时间一直在忙网页建设的事，板子到手后只焊了十个电阻，等我把bug改完就会继续开焊喽，到时候再继续更新这篇文章。

entry.title: 关于本站/本人
entry.content:
建站想法

博主本人不善交际，平日里沉默寡言，也无人关注。按照心理咨询师所说，我算是有些许精神问题吧，整日被坏情绪折磨，每隔一段时间都要开始一段自闭期。曾经有次注销了空间，删光了所有朋友圈，也屏蔽了所有人的动态，再也没有打开过。自从这样做之后，我的世界似乎寂静了许多。有着这样扭曲的人格，我自然是没什么朋友。

偶然一次查找技术资料时，看到了某位博主搭建的个人博客，记载了许多技术知识与生活感悟，界面朴素但内容丰富，就像一个可以无所不谈的私人小窝。突然我也萌生了搭建个人博客的想法。既然不想发动态去打扰到他人视线，那就永远不发了，将该记录的事物记录在自己的小站，想知道我近况的人自然会来看，如此，安静又笃定。我会发表一些技术文章，希望能帮助到一些素不相识的人。

关于我

目前就读于北京理工大学电子科学与技术专业的一个本科生，是个无趣、不热爱生活的人。生活黯淡无光，但也渴望光照射进来。永远都在孤独，永远都在情绪内耗，永远爱音乐。

本站浏览指南

主页内容

本人个人博客的域名为 www.greatbastard.space ，移动端主页点击右上角的目录图标即可展开目录，目前有搜索本站功能，文章、分类、标签、留言板、碎碎念界面。

主页的封面上有一些博主精选的句子(装文艺)，中心位置是近期发表的文章，左侧是一些卡片式信息，有我的github主页、邮箱以及微信。归档卡片会以时间轴的形式以月为单位将文章分类，网站资讯卡片提供一些基础数据展示。

评论区

文章界面和一些特殊界面会开放评论区，需要填写自己的昵称、邮箱(建议使用QQ邮箱以获取头像)、个人网址(非必填)来发表评论，支持Markdown语法，没有使用过Markdown的朋友可以直接输入内容，也可以在bing/百度查询语法内容，十分简单，可以快速掌握。输入过程中可以点击预览来查看Markdown文本渲染后的效果。评论框左下角可以选择插入表情与图片，也可以在输入框中直接输入图片网址来插入图片。

留言板

留言板界面开放评论区，有什么想告诉博主的可以直接在评论区发送。

碎碎念

在碎碎念界面，博主会发表一些很短的文章，记录近况。

Tidio实时在线聊天功能

如果你有比较要紧的事情想要联系博主，可以点击右下角悬浮窗中的”SMS”图标，输入邮箱登录后即可给博主发送消息，博主的手机会立刻收到提醒，应该可以及时做出回复。

页面底部Aplayer全局音乐播放器

通过js脚本植入，音源、歌词以及封面文件托管在又拍云存储。博主选择了一些个人很喜欢的歌曲放在歌单里，播放器默认随机播放，也可以点开详情选择歌曲、修改播放模式。

最后一件事

如果你在浏览过程中发现bug，请及时联系我哦，我会尽快修复，感激不尽！

就这些，希望你浏览愉快。
